title: Visualise Variable Selection Instability
text: Data-driven variable selection (e.g., stepwise selection) typically involve conditional decisions complicate inference yet invite ‘one-true model’ interpretation. Issues approach well documented scientific literature [Harrell, 2015; Steyerberg, 2009]: Biased parameter estimates (‘testimation’ bias) Confidence intervals narrow; p-values exaggerated; model R2 biased large Detaches thought selection risking nonsensical removal clinically (subject matter) relevant variables Despite known issues, application persists published analyses clinical data [Zamanipoor et al., 2020]. care taken, incorrect variable ‘selections’ perpetuated future hypotheses, consequently wasting effort & resource. effective way representing model uncertainty induced variable selection consider long run frequency variables selected applied sufficient number bootstrap samples drawn original training-set. Strong (necessarily real!) “outcome-predictor” effects typically come majority () bootstrap fits. number known predictors might expected appear “typically” final fit, guarantees. Bootstrap sampling can used emulate natural perturbations might occurred originally collecting data: summarising impact perturbations final model can powerful insightful way explore problem, particularly conveying message non-quantitative colleagues [Heinze et al., 2018]. introduce ‘Tetris plot’ associated {tetrisplot} package way visualising instability.

what: Inspecting model (in)stability and novel ways to present this
title: Visualise Variable Selection Instability
text: 2018 paper, Heinze et al. outlined possible empirically estimate marginal joint variable selection probabilities repeatedly applying data-driven selection steps 100’s re-sampled bootstrap draws (replacement) sample data. intuition value leveraging variable selection uncertainty (therefore model uncertainty) implicit across bootstrap re-samples. table Figure 1 illustrates bootstrap selection across set p candidate covariates, xi  = 1, 2, …, p − 1, p. xi variable inclusion probability pxi estimated averaging column-wise indicator total bootstrap samples, B. exists set 2p + 1 unique combinations selected xi variables (including intercept model). However, given data, model, selection criteria, equally likely. observed frequency unique joint combinations B draws can derived expose . ‘Tetris plot’ therefore aims bring bootstrap results life, acting visual representation dangers lurk reifying observed final data-driven selection.

title: Visualise Variable Selection Instability
text: Using data available {tetrisplot} package now illustrate output visualisations available selection methods implemented package. simple call associated plot() method outputs:
code: data(iswr_stroke)  vec <- colnames(iswr_stroke)[colnames(iswr_stroke) != "dead12"]  boot_dat <- bootstrap_data(iswr_stroke,                             times = 100)  boot_univariate <- analyse_univariate(boot_dat,                                       response = "dead12",                                       vars = vec,                                        family = "binomial",                                        level = 0.05)  boot_backward <- analyse_backward(boot_dat,                                   response = "dead12",                                   vars = vec,                                    family = "binomial")  boot_lasso <- analyse_grlasso(boot_dat,                               response = "dead12",                               vars = vec,                                family = "binomial",                               grpreg_list = list(penalty = "grLasso"))

title: Visualise Variable Selection Instability
text: Dalgaard, P. (2020). ISwR: Introductory Statistics R. R package version 2.0-8 Harrell, F. E. (2015). Regression Modeling Strategies: Applications Linear Models, Logistic Ordinal Regression, Survival Analysis. Springer International Publishing Heinze, G., Wallisch, C., & Dunkler, D. (2018). Variable selection – review recommendations practicing statistician. Biometrical Journal, 60(3), 431–449. https://doi.org/10.1002/bimj.201700067 Steyerberg, E. W. (2009). Clinical Prediction Models: Practical Approach Development, Validation, Updating. Springer International Publishing Zamanipoor Najafabadi, . H., et al. (2020). TRIPOD statement: preliminary pre-post analysis reporting methods prediction models. BMJ Open, 10(9), 1–10. https://doi.org/10.1136/bmjopen-2020-041537

what: Backward stepwise selection using AIC — analyse_backward
title: Backward stepwise selection using AIC — analyse_backward
text: application backward stepwise selection using AIC criterion stepping (.e., full model) candidate set variables.

title: Backward stepwise selection using AIC — analyse_backward
code: analyse_backward(   x,   response = NULL,   vars = NULL,   family = stats::gaussian(),   k = 2 )

title: Backward stepwise selection using AIC — analyse_backward
text: x output bootstrap_data function. response character argument denoting outcome. vars character vector denoting covariates features screened. family error distribution link function passed glm() call inside analyse_backward function. Default gaussian. k per stats::step definition: "multiple number degrees freedom used penalty".

title: Backward stepwise selection using AIC — analyse_backward
text: nested tibble.

title: Backward stepwise selection using AIC — analyse_backward
text: present function simple wrapper stats::step() function. various commentaries published use stepwise selection, range interpretations utility, spanning generous proponents focussing simplicity reduced model "insignificant" variables removed, highlight invalidates statistical inference can drawn final fit. Irrespective stance taken, method still common practice many clinical prediction modelling publications thus worth including illustrating selection instability.

title: Backward stepwise selection using AIC — analyse_backward
text: Harrell, F. E. (2015). Regression Modeling Strategies: Applications Linear Models, Logistic Ordinal Regression, Survival Analysis. Springer International Publishing. https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=sQ90rgEACAAJ

title: Backward stepwise selection using AIC — analyse_backward
code: data(iswr_stroke) iswr_stroke %>%   bootstrap_data(10, seed = 1234) %>%   analyse_backward(response = "dead12",                    vars = c("Gender", "Age", "Diagnosis", "Coma",                             "Diabetes", "MI", "Hypertension"),                    family = "binomial") #> # A tibble: 10 × 3 #>    boot_rep data               vars      #>       <int> <list>             <list>    #>  1        1 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [5]> #>  2        2 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [7]> #>  3        3 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [5]> #>  4        4 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [6]> #>  5        5 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [5]> #>  6        6 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [4]> #>  7        7 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [6]> #>  8        8 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [4]> #>  9        9 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [5]> #> 10       10 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [6]>

what: Grouped LASSO penalisation for shrinkage with selection — analyse_grlasso
title: Grouped LASSO penalisation for shrinkage with selection — analyse_grlasso
text: application Grouped LASSO penalisation. Whilst group LASSO may used generally pre-specify arbitrary groupings variables, used ensure selection entire categorical variables one dummy level.

title: Grouped LASSO penalisation for shrinkage with selection — analyse_grlasso
code: analyse_grlasso(   x,   response = NULL,   vars = NULL,   family = "gaussian",   grpreg_list = list(NULL) )

title: Grouped LASSO penalisation for shrinkage with selection — analyse_grlasso
text: x output bootstrap_data function. response character argument denoting outcome. vars character vector denoting covariates features screened. family error distribution link function passed grpreg() call inside analyse_grlasso function. Currently gaussian, binomial poisson supported grpreg package present default set "gaussian". grpreg_list list passed grpreg::grpreg call. See ?grpreg::grpreg details.

title: Grouped LASSO penalisation for shrinkage with selection — analyse_grlasso
text: present function simple wrapper grpreg::grpreg() function. Grouped LASSO extends standard LASSO penalty introduction grouping index. therefore applies variable selection group level.

title: Grouped LASSO penalisation for shrinkage with selection — analyse_grlasso
code: data(iswr_stroke) iswr_stroke %>%   bootstrap_data(10, seed = 1234) %>%   analyse_grlasso(response = "dead12",                   vars = c("Gender", "Age", "Diagnosis", "Coma",                            "Diabetes", "MI", "Hypertension"),                   family = "binomial",                   grpreg_list = list(penalty = "grLasso")) #> # A tibble: 10 × 3 #>    boot_rep data               vars      #>       <int> <list>             <list>    #>  1        1 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [6]> #>  2        2 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [7]> #>  3        3 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [7]> #>  4        4 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [7]> #>  5        5 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [7]> #>  6        6 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [7]> #>  7        7 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [7]> #>  8        8 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [4]> #>  9        9 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [6]> #> 10       10 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [7]>

title: Uni-variate variable selection — analyse_univariate
text: univariate screening covariates outcome.

title: Uni-variate variable selection — analyse_univariate
code: analyse_univariate(   x,   response = NULL,   vars = NULL,   level = 0.05,   family = stats::gaussian(),   method = "Wald" )

title: Uni-variate variable selection — analyse_univariate
text: x output bootstrap_data function. response character argument denoting outcome. vars character vector denoting covariates features screened. level numeric scalar denoting significance threshold used uni-variate test performed. Default 0.05. family error distribution link function passed glm() call inside analyse_univariate function. Default gaussian. method character value chosen test used. Currently Wald Chi-squared test implemented.

title: Uni-variate variable selection — analyse_univariate
text: nested tibble.

title: Uni-variate variable selection — analyse_univariate
text: number analysis wrappers created illustrate challenge final variable selection. can combined sequence desired user consider combinations selection per bootstrap replication. Although discouraged (Moons et al., 2012), univariate selection uncommon, particularly way pre-screen many covariates prior multi-variable fit possible feature selection thereafter. present function simple wrapper aod::wald.test() function, implementation Wald Chi-squared test assumption asymptotic (multivariate) normality.

title: Uni-variate variable selection — analyse_univariate
text: Moons, K. G. M., Kengne, . P., Woodward, M., Royston, P., Vergouwe, Y., Altman, D. G., & Grobbee, D. E. (2012). Risk prediction models: . Development, internal validation, assessing incremental value new (bio)marker. Heart, 98(9), 683–690. https://doi.org/10.1136/heartjnl-2011-301246

title: Uni-variate variable selection — analyse_univariate
code: data(iswr_stroke) iswr_stroke %>%    bootstrap_data(10, seed = 1234) %>%   analyse_univariate(response = "dead12",                      vars = c("Gender", "Age", "Diagnosis", "Coma",                                "Diabetes", "MI", "Hypertension"),                      family = "binomial",                               level = 0.05) #> # A tibble: 10 × 3 #>    boot_rep data               vars      #>       <int> <list>             <list>    #>  1        1 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [3]> #>  2        2 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [5]> #>  3        3 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [5]> #>  4        4 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [7]> #>  5        5 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [5]> #>  6        6 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [3]> #>  7        7 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [5]> #>  8        8 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [2]> #>  9        9 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [4]> #> 10       10 <tibble [814 × 8]> <chr [4]>

what: Bootstrapped data sets with replacement — bootstrap_data

text: user provided data set number bootstrapped samples generated replacement.

title: Bootstrapped data sets with replacement — bootstrap_data
code: bootstrap_data(data, times, include_original = FALSE, seed = NULL, ...)

title: Bootstrapped data sets with replacement — bootstrap_data
text: data data frame generate bootstrap samples. times numeric input specifying many bootstrap draws generated data. include_original logical input. TRUE returned output contain row original data. Default FALSE (see details). seed numeric input specifying seed used. Default NULL ... dots future extensions must empty.

title: Bootstrapped data sets with replacement — bootstrap_data
text: nested tibble

title: Bootstrapped data sets with replacement — bootstrap_data
text: Note design bootstrapped sample size original data set. function generates simple random sample replacement along number rows provided data. suitability making inference bootstrapped samples depend variety points (eg. size original N, number boot strap draws generated) left user decide warranted. include_original argument can useful obtain apparent selection given variable selection method.

title: Bootstrapped data sets with replacement — bootstrap_data
code: test_dat <- data.frame(a = 1:5, b = rnorm(5)) bootstrap_data(test_dat, times = 2, seed = 123)  #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   boot_rep data         #>      <int> <list>       #> 1        1 <df [5 × 2]> #> 2        2 <df [5 × 2]>

Estonian stroke data — iswr_stroke
text: Taken package {ISwR}, example dataset cases stroke Tartu, Estonia, period 1991–1993, follow-January 1, 1996. main edits decorate specified variable types define binary classification "dead alive" 12 months initial stroke.

title: Estonian stroke data — iswr_stroke
text: data frame 814 rows 8 columns: Gender Patient's gender, coded factor variable levels Male Female Age Patients age recorded integer Diagnosis Patient's diagnosis denoting type stroke: ICH, ID, INF, SAH Coma Whether patient fell coma time original stroke, coded factor variable levels  Yes Diabetes Patient's history diabetes, coded factor variable levels Yes MI Patient's history myocardial infarction, coded factor variable levels Yes Hypertension Patient's history Hypertension, coded factor variable levels Yes dead12 Denoting whether patient died 12 months , coded numeric variable 1 = yes, 0 =

title: Estonian stroke data — iswr_stroke
text: https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/ISwR/index.html

what: Plot of bootstrapped variable selections — plot
title: Plot of bootstrapped variable selections — plot
text: Produces "tetris plot" highlighting uncertainty selection variables chosen repeat sampling.

title: Plot of bootstrapped variable selections — plot
code: plot(x, ...)  # S3 method for tetris_analysis plot(x, k = 0, ...)

title: Plot of bootstrapped variable selections — plot
text: x output analysis_ function class tetris_analysis. ... Currently unused. k numeric input used truncate number columns "tetris plot". Defaults 0 meaning restriction.

title: Plot of bootstrapped variable selections — plot
text: patchwork two ggplot outputs.

title: Plot of bootstrapped variable selections — plot
text: cases may large number combinations along columns plot (joint selection probabilities). scenarios can occur many joint selection combinations empirical size 1/times times number bootstrap draws.  circumstances might desired restrict "top set" ignores less frequent combinations - effectively "zooming" left-hand-side "tetris plot".

title: Plot of bootstrapped variable selections — plot
code: data(iswr_stroke) iswr_stroke %>%   bootstrap_data(10, seed = 1234) %>%   analyse_univariate(response = "dead12",                      vars = c("Gender", "Age", "Diagnosis", "Coma",                               "Diabetes", "MI", "Hypertension"),                      family = "binomial") %>%    plot()

title: Summarise bootstrapped variable selection — summary
text: Alongside plot, can also useful extract numbers behind "tetris plot".

title: Summarise bootstrapped variable selection — summary
code: summary(x, type = "marginal", ...)  # S3 method for tetris_analysis summary(x, type = "marginal", ...)

title: Summarise bootstrapped variable selection — summary
text: x output analysis_ function class tetris_analysis type character input either "marginal" (default) "joint" ... Currently unused.

title: Summarise bootstrapped variable selection — summary
text: tibble appended joint marginal probabilities

title: Summarise bootstrapped variable selection — summary
text: summary method essentially derives two types  empirical results associated generated bootstrap analyses

title: Summarise bootstrapped variable selection — summary
code: data(iswr_stroke) iswr_stroke %>%   bootstrap_data(10, seed = 1234) %>%   analyse_univariate(response = "dead12",                      vars = c("Gender", "Age", "Diagnosis", "Coma",                               "Diabetes", "MI", "Hypertension"),                      family = "binomial") %>%    summary() #> # A tibble: 7 × 2 #>   vars          prop #>   <chr>        <dbl> #> 1 Age            1   #> 2 Coma           0.7 #> 3 Diabetes       0.3 #> 4 Diagnosis      0.1 #> 5 Gender         0.9 #> 6 Hypertension   0.4 #> 7 MI             0.9
